title: Front Brake Disc - Installation

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle Including locking devices
Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Note to be used in service manual with stabilise warning
Renew locking devices where specified, refer to
Before tightening a fixing using a crow foot spanner adapter, refer to
Use of Crow Foot Spanner Adapters with Torque Wrenches
Observe all torque wrench tightening procedures, refer to
Front Disc Install DU4 DT4 DTC DUB DTB DUC
Check the front brake dampers for deterioration and cracks, replace if necessary.
Fit the front brake dampers to the wheel as noted for removal, making sure the alignment mark on the damper aligns with the alignment mark on the wheel.
Front wheel hub alignment mark (right hand side)
Front wheel hub alignment mark (left hand side)
The ABS pulser ring is to be fitted to the left hand brake disc.
Locate the brake disc and ABS pulser ring to the wheel as noted during removal.
Make sure the brake disc fixings are tightened in the three stage sequence detailed below.
: Fit new brake disc fixings. Tighten the fixings in the sequence below to
Tighten the fixings in the sequence below to
Brake Disc Fixings Tightening Sequence (Left Hand Side Shown)
Make sure the brake disc fixings are tightened in the three stage sequence detailed below.
Locate the brake disc to the right hand side of the wheel.
: Fit new brake disc fixings. Tighten the fixings in the sequence below to
Tighten the fixings in the sequence below to

body.name: Font RH Brake Disc Tighten DT4 DU4 (cjeu_2_2)

body.body: Brake Disc Fixings Tightening Sequence (Right Hand Side Shown)
Check the front wheel is free to rotate. If the front wheel is not free to rotate, contact Triumph Service.
Check and, if necessary, adjust the air gap between the wheel speed sensor and the ABS pulser ring (see
Check the operation of the front brake. Rectify as necessary.

It is dangerous to operate the motorcycle with defective brakes; you must have your authorised Triumph dealer take remedial action before you attempt to ride the motorcycle again. Failure to take remedial action may reduce braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
